text.p: CSX Corp., which has agreed to merge with Conrail Inc. in a $9.3 billion deal, said Tuesday it challenged a petition filed by Norfolk Southern Corp. with regulators to overrule a provision that prohibits Conrail from seeking another merger partner before 1999.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, CSX said it filed the challenge on Monday with the Surface Transportation Board (STB), a federal agency that oversees railroads.

Norfolk Southern, which has offered $10.5 billion for Philadelphia-based Conrail, asked the Surface Transportation Board on Dec. 27 to rule that the provision "constitutes unlawful control by one railroad over another."
Norfolk Southern has offered $115 per share in cash, while CSX, based in Richmond, Va., has offered a combination of cash and stock that is worth about $102 a share.
Both companies raised their bids earlier this month. At the same time Conrail and CSX extended the so-called exclusivity period to Dec. 31, 1998 from July 1997.
